Fed-QSSL: A Framework for Personalized Federated Learning under Bitwidth and Data Heterogeneity

Yiyue Chen1, Haris Vikalo1, Chianing Wang2 This work was supported by Toyota Motor North America.
( 1The University of Texas at Austin
2Toyota InfoTech Lab USA
yiyuechen@utexas.edu, hvikalo@utexas.edu, johnny.wang@toyota.com )
Abstract

Motivated by high resource costs of centralized machine learning schemes as well as data privacy concerns, federated learning (FL) emerged as an efficient alternative that relies on aggregating locally trained models rather than collecting clients’ potentially private data. In practice, available resources and data distributions vary from one client to another, creating an inherent system heterogeneity that leads to deterioration of the performance of conventional FL algorithms. In this work, we present a federated quantization-based self-supervised learning scheme (Fed-QSSL) designed to address heterogeneity in FL systems. At clients’ side, to tackle data heterogeneity we leverage distributed self-supervised learning while utilizing low-bit quantization to satisfy constraints imposed by local infrastructure and limited communication resources. At server’s side, Fed-QSSL deploys de-quantization, weighted aggregation and re-quantization, ultimately creating models personalized to both data distribution as well as specific infrastructure of each client’s device. We validated the proposed algorithm on real world datasets, demonstrating its efficacy, and theoretically analyzed impact of low-bit training on the convergence and robustness of the learned models.


1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [27, 18] recently emerged in response to the challenges in data privacy, storage cost and computation commonly faced by the conventional (centralized) learning systems. In centralized learning, a server collects and stores data to be used for model training, raising concerns regarding potential leakage of sensitive information and inefficient utilization of the storage and computation resources. Lately, advancements in software and hardware technologies have equipped smart edge devices with computational power that enables local data processing, allowing implementation of distributed frameworks such as FL in a variety of real-world applications [7]. In FL systems, participating devices collaboratively learn a model while preserving privacy by training on local data that remains private. A server aggregates local updates to obtain a global model which is then distributed to the clients; in turn, the clients continue local training using the latest global model as a starting point. In addition to the conventional supervised learning, federated learning is suitable for meta-learning and unsupervised learning problems [16, 31].

Heterogeneity in local data distribution, as well as imbalance in the computation and memory capabilities of the participating devices, present major challenges to federated learning [39, 36]. Practical scenarios where both sources of heterogeneity occur include healthcare disorder prediction for patients with different profiles and monitoring devices, transportation systems over different vehicles and terrain, and indoor/outdoor air quality detection, to name just a few. Several recent FL techniques aim to alleviate the impact of data, model or device heterogeneity [15, 24, 9, 34]. However, variations in bitwidth available to the clients that participate in training have been much less studied [36]. To our knowledge, there exists no prior work in literature investigating FL in setting where both the local data and device bitwidth are heterogeneous – the focus of our work.

On one hand, clients’ devices collect and/or generate data at different times and locations, leading to discrepancy in data amounts and distribution. When distributed devices train locally, each learned model optimizes an objective specified in regard to a local dataset. If the data across participating devices is non-IID, the devices end up optimizing distinct objectives which generally adversely affects training convergence and, ultimately, negatively impacts performance of the resulting global model trained by classical FL algorithms such as FedAvg [27, 23]. This is exacerbated when a client’s dataset contains only a small subset of classes or few data points, leading to an insufficiently expressive local model. In turn, using such models in the aggregation step at the server leads to a global model that lacks robustness and in general may significantly underperform its centrally trained counterparts [39].

On the other hand, to satisfy the constraints on local compute and memory footprint as well as on the communication bandwidth between clients and the central server, each client needs to train a local model in low bitwidth operations and store the updated model in low bitwidth [36]. When the clients’ devices have different bitwidth capabilities, a number of novel challenges arise including: (1) Quantized training conducted at lower precision levels does not necessarily lead to expressive local model; (2) the server needs to aggregate local models that are represented by different number of bits; and (3) following the aggregation of local updates, the server should communicate to clients the new global model re-quantized at levels matching the capabilities of different devices. Prior works that deploy model compression in distributed settings focus on reducing the communication cost [30, 5, 6]; those methods utilize full precision weights in the training process rather than trying to train under weight precision constraint. To address the problem of aggregating models trained at different precision, [36] proposed a progressive weight de-quantizer that transforms low precision models to their full precision versions before aggregating them. The de-quantizer there requires the server to train DenseNet for de-quantizing low precision models; the method assumes the local data distribution is the same across different clients and thus does not apply to the heterogeneous data settings studied in this paper. Note that all of these methods are restricted to supervised learning.

The contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    For the first time, a novel FL problem characterized by heterogeneous local data distributions and varied capabilities of clients’ devices is studied. This is the first work to consider the non-trivial task of aggregating models which due to varied bitwidth and heterogeneous data have incompatible parameters and different expressiveness. While prior work addresses either source of heterogeneity in isolation of the other, to our knowledge the combination of the two has not been investigated previously. Indeed, new challenges set forth by the combination of the heterogeneity sources render the prior techniques ineffective.

  2. 2.

    We present a new FL framework, Fed-QSSL, that enables learning personalized and robust low-bitwidth models in settings characterized by diverse infrastructure and data distributions. Fed-QSSL combines low-bitwidth quantization training with self-supervised learning at the client side, and deploys de-quantization, weighted aggregation and re-quantization at the server side.

  3. 3.

    We theoretically analyze the impact of low-bit training on the convergence and robustness of learned models. In particular, we present a bound on the variance of the quantization errors in local and global training and investigate the associated convergence speed. The analysis demonstrates that low-bit training with Fed-QSSL on heterogeneous data allows learning meaningful representations.

  4. 4.

    Finally, the efficacy of the proposed algorithm is tested in a variety of experiments.

1.1 Related work

Bitwidth heterogeneity in FL. To address local infrastructure constraints, [9] rely on models with simple architectures and low-bit parameter representation. However, existing prior work typically assumes that clients train models of same precision, e.g., the same bitwidth, which may often be violated in practice since the participating devices generally have different computational power and/or memory footprint. The varying infrastructure capabilities of the clients’ devices imply that the models they are able to deploy differ in size, i.e., devices with more computational power and memory allow models of higher precision (e.g., 16-bit and 32-bit) while less capable devices may only handle low-precision models (e.g., those storing parameters in 2-bit or 4-bit precision). To satisfy local infrastructure constraints, not only should a model be represented and stored at reduced precision levels but the training process should also rely on operations at such levels (i.e., perform quantized training in low-bitwidth). Recently, [36] studied the bitwidth heterogeneity problem in FL and proposed a progressive de-quantization of the received local models prior to their aggregation into a global model.

Quantized neural network training. When the compute/storage resources are limited, on-device training of deep neural networks at full precision is rendered infeasible. To this end, recent works have explored model size reduction and the training that leads to low bitwidth weights/activations. These include binarized neural networks (BNN) and XNOR-Net which binarize the weights and activations of convolutional layers to reduce the computation complexity in the forward pass [13, 29]. Specifically, in the forward pass the computationally expensive convolutional operations are implemented via bitwise operation kernels that evaluate the dot product of binary vectors x and 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y}

x⋅𝐲=bitcount​(and​(x,𝐲)),xi,yi∈{0,1}​∀i,formulae-sequence⋅x𝐲bitcountandx𝐲subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖01for-all𝑖\displaystyle{\textbf{x}}\cdot\mathbf{y}=\mathrm{bitcount}(\mathrm{and}({\textbf{x}},\mathbf{y})),x_{i},y_{i}\in\{0,1\}\ \forall i,

where bitcount​(⋅)bitcount⋅\mathrm{bitcount}(\cdot) counts the number of bits in its argument. Such a kernel can be generalized to accommodate operations on M𝑀M-bit fixed-point integer sequence x𝑥x and K𝐾K-bit fixed-point integer sequence y𝑦y, incurring computation complexity of 𝒪​(M​K)𝒪𝑀𝐾{\mathcal{O}}(MK) (i.e., the complexity is proportional to the vector bitwidths). Related work [40] presents DoReFa-Net which reduces the backpropagation computation cost by quantizing gradients in the backward pass, and studies the effect of the weight, activation and gradient bitwidth choice on the model performance. Subsequent works include techniques that deploy training without floating-point operations, gradient clipping, and training under mixed precision [35, 37, 41, 38]. While all of the aforementioned methods investigate quantization in supervised learning settings, recently there has been interest in quantizing models for self-supervised learning. In [2], the authors propose self-supervised and quantization learning (SSQL), which contrasts features learned from the quantized and full precision models in order to provide reasonable accuracy of quantized models and boost the accuracy of the full precision model. While this work can balance the accuracy and bitwidth in resource constrained settings, it still requires full precision operations and gradient storage during training.

Non-IID data and distributed self-supervised learning. There have been multiple efforts to ameliorate the impact of data heterogeneity on the performance of distributed learning systems [19, 10, 21]. Recently, self-supervised learning (SSL) has been shown effective in distributed settings where the data is large-scale and imbalanced [34]. In contrast to supervised learning, which requires large amount of labeled data for model training, self-supervised learning defines a pre-train task that enables extracting expressive representations; those representations can then be utilized in various downstream tasks in computer vision and natural language processing [3, 4]. While the majority of self-supervised learning methods focus on the centralized setting where the data is collected for central training, recent works have attempted to bridge the self-supervised and federated learning [11, 42, 26].

2 Preliminaries

Let us consider a federated learning system with n𝑛n clients, where the clients rely on privately owned data to collaboratively learn a global model. Rather than communicating the data, the clients send to a coordinating central server the models trained locally. In turn, the server forms a global model by aggregating the received local models, and re-distributes the global model back to the clients for further local training. Let Dk={xk,i}i=1|Dk|subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}=\{x_{k,i}\}_{i=1}^{|D_{k}|} denote the data owned by client k𝑘k, where xk,i∼𝒟ksimilar-tosubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝒟𝑘x_{k,i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k} is a d𝑑d-dimensional data point in Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} and |Dk|subscript𝐷𝑘|D_{k}| denotes the number of local data points. The distribution 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} of data varies from one client to another, leading to system-wide data heterogeneity. The union D=⋃k=1nDk𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘D=\bigcup_{k=1}^{n}D_{k} is assumed to be a dataset of uniform distribution, i.e., the data classes in D𝐷D are balanced.

In self-supervised learning problems, an embedding function fw​(⋅)subscript𝑓w⋅f_{{\textbf{w}}}(\cdot), parameterized by w, is learned as a feature extractor for extracting expressive representations from data. In particular, we will denote the representation vector for point x𝑥x by fw​(x)subscript𝑓w𝑥f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x); such a representation vector is then used for downstream tasks such as image classification or object detection. Contrastive learning is a popular methodology for identifying the embedding function fw​(⋅)subscript𝑓w⋅f_{{\textbf{w}}}(\cdot) [3]. The aim of contrastive learning is to find an embedding function such that the distance between the learned representations of data point x𝑥x and its positive signal x+superscript𝑥x^{+} (generated from x𝑥x) is small, while the distance between the representations of x𝑥x and negative samples x−superscript𝑥x^{-} (extracted from the training batch) is large.111Given a data sample x𝑥x, its positive signal may be a variant obtained by adding noise, changing color, or clipping; negative signals include data samples from different classes, or simply other data samples in the same training batch. A commonly used objective in contrastive learning is the InfoNCE loss; specifically, the local objective for client k𝑘k is

ℒC​L,k​(w)=1|Dk|​∑i=1|Dk|−log⁡(𝔻k,i+𝔻k,i++∑j𝔻k,i,j−),subscriptℒ𝐶𝐿𝑘w1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑖subscript𝑗superscriptsubscript𝔻𝑘𝑖𝑗\mathcal{L}_{CL,k}({\textbf{w}})=\frac{1}{|D_{k}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|D_{k}|}-\log(\frac{\mathbb{D}_{k,i}^{+}}{\mathbb{D}_{k,i}^{+}+\sum_{j}\mathbb{D}_{k,i,j}^{-}}),

where 𝔻k,i+=exp(−𝔻(fw(xk,i),fw(xk,i+))/τ\mathbb{D}_{k,i}^{+}=\exp(-\mathbb{D}(f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x_{k,i}),f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x_{k,i}^{+}))/\tau, 𝔻k,i,j−=exp(−𝔻(fw(xk,i),fw(xk,j−))/τ\mathbb{D}_{k,i,j}^{-}=\exp(-\mathbb{D}(f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x_{k,i}),f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x_{k,j}^{-}))/\tau, and τ>0𝜏0\tau>0 is a temperature parameter controlling the sharpness of the exponential term. The function 𝔻​(⋅)𝔻⋅\mathbb{D}(\cdot) is typically defined as the cosine distance, i.e., 𝔻​(z1,z2)=−z1⋅z2‖z1‖​‖z2‖𝔻subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2⋅subscript𝑧1subscript𝑧2normsubscript𝑧1normsubscript𝑧2\mathbb{D}(z_{1},z_{2})=-\frac{z_{1}\cdot z_{2}}{\|z_{1}\|\|z_{2}\|}. Note that instead of the negative sample term, an alternative SSL strategy adds to the objective a feature prediction function g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) that helps avoid potential collapse i.e. low accuracy of the trained classifier layer [4]; in that case, the objective becomes

ℒs​i​a​m,k​(w)=1|Dk|​∑i=1|Dk|𝔻​(g​(fw​(xk,i)),fw​(xk,i+)).subscriptℒ𝑠𝑖𝑎𝑚𝑘w1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘𝔻𝑔subscript𝑓wsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑓wsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖\mathcal{L}_{siam,k}({\textbf{w}})=\frac{1}{|D_{k}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|D_{k}|}\mathbb{D}(g(f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x_{k,i})),f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x_{k,i}^{+})).

In federated learning, each client has a local data source Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}. The clients collaboratively search for w that minimizes the global objective function

ℒ​(w)=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​ℒk​(w).ℒwsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscriptℒ𝑘w\displaystyle\mathcal{L}({\textbf{w}})=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}\mathcal{L}_{k}({\textbf{w}}). (1)

To solve this distributed optimization without data sharing, numerous federated learning schemes have been proposed including the FedAvg algorithm [27]. At each iteration of FedAvg, central server samples a subset of clients which then run E𝐸E local update epochs. The server collects updated models from the selected clients and aggregates them to form a global model, which is distributed to all clients for further local training/inference. The number of local training epochs, E𝐸E, controls the computation-communication tradeoff, i.e., larger E𝐸E leads to less frequent communication.

We further assume that participating clients have devices with varied compute, memory and communication capabilities, and therefore train and deploy models at different bitwidth precision. Let sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} denote the number of bits used to represent parameters wksubscriptw𝑘{\textbf{w}}_{k} of the model deployed by client k𝑘k. When training, client k𝑘k utilizes bit convolutional kernels and conducts operations on sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}-bit objects rather than performing full precision (i.e., 323232-bit floating-point) operations. When aggregating the collected local models into global model wGsubscriptw𝐺{\textbf{w}}_{G}, the server takes into consideration that the models are trained at different precision levels. The server itself is assumed to be capable of performing operations at full precision. Finally, the global model is compressed to various low bitwidth representations and sent to the corresponding clients, i.e., client k𝑘k receives updated model in sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} bit representation.

In our proposed framework, client k𝑘k performs low-bit training to learn parameters wksubscriptw𝑘{\textbf{w}}_{k} of its local model; note that the low-bit training and quantization are deployed in all steps, including the forward pass, backpropagation and model update. In each round of training, model parameters in sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}-bit representation are fed into the forward pass via bit convolution kernels, and the gradient computed from the backward propagation is quantized and stored. After updating the model by using gradient descent, the model parameters are quantized to sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} bits and stored.

3 Algorithm

The proposed federated quantized self-supervised learning scheme consists of training procedures deployed at clients’ devices and the server, as detailed next.

At each client’s side, a feature extraction model is trained in low bitwidth with layer-wise quantization in both forward and backward propagation pass. We denote the model parameters of client k𝑘k in training epoch t𝑡t by wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}; each parameter is represented using sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} bits. The codebook used for quantizing parameters of each layer of the model, wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}, has cardinality 2sksuperscript2subscript𝑠𝑘2^{s_{k}}. The quantization centers (i.e., codebook entries) are typically determined via uniform quantization [40],

ro=quantizes​(ri)=12s−1​round​((2s−1)​ri),subscript𝑟𝑜subscriptquantize𝑠subscript𝑟𝑖1superscript2𝑠1roundsuperscript2𝑠1subscript𝑟𝑖\displaystyle r_{o}=\mathrm{quantize}_{s}(r_{i})=\frac{1}{2^{s}-1}\mathrm{round}((2^{s}-1)r_{i}),

which uses a uniform quantizer quantizessubscriptquantize𝑠\mathrm{quantize}_{s} to map a real-valued input ri∈[0,1]subscript𝑟𝑖01r_{i}\in[0,1] to an s𝑠s-bit output ro∈[0,1]subscript𝑟𝑜01r_{o}\in[0,1]. In general, parameters of deep neural networks do not follow uniform distribution and may vary in range. Therefore, the parameters may first need to be non-linearly transformed, e.g., by applying tanh\tanh function to limit their range to [−1,1]11[-1,1]. If tanh\tanh function is used, the quantized model weights are found as

ro=2​q​u​a​n​t​i​z​es​(tanh⁡ri2​max⁡(tanh⁡ri)+12)−1,subscript𝑟𝑜2quantizsubscripte𝑠subscript𝑟𝑖2subscript𝑟𝑖121\displaystyle r_{o}=2\mathrm{quantize}_{s}(\frac{\tanh{r_{i}}}{2\max(\tanh{r_{i}})}+\frac{1}{2})-1,

where the maximum is taken over all parameters in the same layer. In the forward pass, we apply normalization to ensure that tanh⁡ri2​max⁡(tanh⁡ri)+12∈[0,1]subscript𝑟𝑖2subscript𝑟𝑖1201\frac{\tanh{r_{i}}}{2\max(\tanh{r_{i}})}+\frac{1}{2}\in[0,1], where max⁡(tanh⁡ri)subscript𝑟𝑖\max(\tanh{r_{i}}) represents the maximum taken over all parameters in this layer. Following the quantization operation, output rosubscript𝑟𝑜r_{o} is in [−1,1]11[-1,1], which improves the stability of training.

In addition to quantizing model parameters, the proposed scheme quantizes activations as well. In particular, after the output of a layer passes through an activation function that guarantees the output to be within [0,1]01[0,1] range, the activation is quantized using quantizessubscriptquantize𝑠\mathrm{quantize}_{s}.

To quantize gradients in backward propagation, we use layer-wise quantile quantization method. In particular, we rely on the inverse of the cumulative distribution function Fgsubscript𝐹gF_{{\textbf{g}}} of the gradients in a layer to define the quantile function Q​u​a​n​t​i​l​eg=Fg−1𝑄𝑢𝑎𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑙subscript𝑒gsubscriptsuperscript𝐹1gQuantile_{{\textbf{g}}}=F^{-1}_{{\textbf{g}}}. The quantization centers are then specified by the end points of each histogram bin, Q​u​a​n​t​i​l​eg​(i2s−1)𝑄𝑢𝑎𝑛𝑡𝑖𝑙subscript𝑒g𝑖superscript2𝑠1Quantile_{{\textbf{g}}}(\frac{i}{2^{s}-1}), for i=0,…,2s−1𝑖0…superscript2𝑠1i=0,\dots,2^{s}-1. It has been observed in prior work on low-bitwidth training [40] that to avoid significant performance degradation, the number of bits for gradient quantization should be no less than the number of bits for weight quantization (and may in fact need to be greater). In our algorithm, local gradient quantization uses 222 bits more than local weight quantization, e.g., if client k𝑘k uses sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} bits for weight/activation quantization then it uses sk+2subscript𝑠𝑘2s_{k}+2 bits for gradient quantization. Following the backward pass, the computed estimate of stochastic gradient, gk,tsubscriptg𝑘𝑡{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}, is immediately quantized to gk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptg𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{g}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}. Finally, updated weights are quantized according to wk,t+1(Q)=Q​(wk,t(Q)−αt​gk,t(Q))subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡1𝑄subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡subscriptsuperscriptg𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t+1}=Q({\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}-\alpha_{t}{\textbf{g}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}).

In each communication round the server collects and de-quantizes local models, aggregates the de-quantized models, re-quantizes the resulting model to low bitwidth and finally distributes the models to clients. To elaborate, after the central server collects local low-bitwidth models, it uses a small buffer of unlabeled data Dgsubscript𝐷𝑔D_{g} to de-quantize the collected local models to full precision. The de-quantization process differs from one local model to another and can be performed in parallel. In the scenario without bitwidth constraints, de-quantization can be viewed as a fine-tuning step on uniform unlabeled data; simulation results presented in the next sections demonstrate that such fine-tuning improves robustness in the full-precision model scenario.

After de-quantizing the collected models, the server forms their weighted average, wt,G=∑k=1npk​wk,t′⁣(Q)subscriptw𝑡𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptsuperscriptw′𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}_{t,G}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}p_{k}{\textbf{w}}^{\prime(Q)}_{k,t}. The weights reflect performance discrepancy among local models caused by both local bitwidth and data heterogeneity, and are computed as

pk=e−ℒD​Qk∑j=1ne−ℒD​Qjsubscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝑒subscriptℒ𝐷subscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛superscript𝑒subscriptℒ𝐷subscript𝑄𝑗\displaystyle p_{k}=\frac{e^{-\mathcal{L}_{DQ_{k}}}}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}e^{-\mathcal{L}_{DQ_{j}}}}

where ℒD​Qksubscriptℒ𝐷subscript𝑄𝑘\mathcal{L}_{DQ_{k}} represents the last epoch loss in the de-quantization process of model k𝑘k. The server re-quantizes global model wt,Gsubscriptw𝑡𝐺{\textbf{w}}_{t,G} to an sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}-bit version denoted by wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t} while running fine-tuning epochs on a uniformly distributed dataset stored in the global buffer Dgsubscript𝐷𝑔D_{g}. The fine-tuning epochs use low-bit operations in order to guarantee that the fine-tuned model stays in sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}-bit representation. Note: both de-quantization and re-quantization use Dgsubscript𝐷𝑔D_{g} for fine-tuning but de-quantization runs full precision operations while re-quantization runs low-bit operations.

After completing pre-training and learning the feature extractor model, each client freezes parameters of the feature extractor model and trains a low-bitwidth classifier on its local (labeled) data.

The described procedure, including both the steps executed by clients as well as those executed by the server, is formalized as Algorithm 1.

Remark. While Algorithm 1 assumes full client participation at each communication round, it is straightforward to incorporate random client sampling as used by the vanilla FedAvg algorithm in settings with a large number of clients. Moreover, when the number of clients is exceedingly large, it may be beneficial to cluster clients with similar data distributions and learn a model for each such cluster, ultimately allowing better utilization of the available resources.

4 Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we present analytical results that provide insights into Fed-QSSL, with a focus on the impact of low-bitwidth training on the convergence and robustness. For the sake of tractability, we consider the SSL formulation utilizing local objective defined as ℒS​S​L,k​(w)=−𝔼​[(w​(xk,i)+ξk,i)T​(w​(xk,i)+ξk,i′)]+12​‖wT​w‖2subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿𝑘w𝔼delimited-[]superscriptwsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝜉𝑘𝑖𝑇wsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜉′𝑘𝑖12superscriptnormsuperscriptw𝑇w2\mathcal{L}_{SSL,k}({\textbf{w}})=-\mathbb{E}[({\textbf{w}}(x_{k,i})+\xi_{k,i})^{T}({\textbf{w}}(x_{k,i})+\xi^{\prime}_{k,i})]+\frac{1}{2}\|{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2}, where ξk,isubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\xi_{k,i} and ξk,i′subscriptsuperscript𝜉′𝑘𝑖\xi^{\prime}_{k,i} denote random noise added to the data sample, while the global objective is defined as ℒS​S​L=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​ℒS​S​L,k​(w)subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿𝑘w\mathcal{L}_{SSL}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}\mathcal{L}_{SSL,k}({\textbf{w}}). This objective is obtained from the InfoNCE loss ℒC​L,ksubscriptℒ𝐶𝐿𝑘\mathcal{L}_{CL,k} by replacing normalization via negative signals by an alternative regularization term [34]. Optimizing ℒS​S​Lsubscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿\mathcal{L}_{SSL} is equivalent to minimizing ℒ​(w)=‖X¯−wT​w‖2ℒwsuperscriptnorm¯𝑋superscriptw𝑇w2\mathcal{L}({\textbf{w}})=\|\bar{X}-{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2} where X¯=∑k|Dk||D|​Xk¯𝑋subscript𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscript𝑋𝑘\bar{X}=\sum_{k}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}X_{k} and Xk=𝔼x∼Dk​(x​xT)=1|Dk|​∑i=1|Dk|xk,i​xk,iTsubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥subscript𝐷𝑘𝑥superscript𝑥𝑇1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝑇X_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim D_{k}}(xx^{T})=\frac{1}{|D_{k}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|D_{k}|}x_{k,i}x_{k,i}^{T}, the empirical covariance matrix of client k𝑘k’s data. Since the aim of this analysis is to assess the impact of low-bitwidth operations at client devices on the convergence and robustness of federated learning, we simplify operations at the server by replacing the sophisticated de-quantizer in Algorithm 1 by a layer-wise codebook mapping low-bitwidth weights to floating-point values according to wk,t′⁣(Q)=wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw′𝑄𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{\prime(Q)}_{k,t}={\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}. The subsequent aggregation follows FedAvg and computes wt,G=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​wk,t′⁣(Q)subscriptw𝑡𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscriptsuperscriptw′𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}_{t,G}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}{\textbf{w}}^{\prime(Q)}_{k,t}, while re-quantization uses a tanh\tanh based quantizer.

For simplicity, we assume that clients quantize weights/activations using the same bitwidth, i.e., s1=s2=⋯=sn=Rsubscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2⋯subscript𝑠𝑛𝑅s_{1}=s_{2}=\cdots=s_{n}=R; moreover, local gradient quantization is performed using the same number of bits. When bitwidth varies across client devices, the devices with higher bitwidth typically have smaller quantization error. Our forthcoming analysis can be viewed as providing error bounds for a system in which clients deploy bitwidth no less than R𝑅R. Local datasets are generated in a distributed and 2​n2𝑛2n-way manner, i.e., local dataset at client k𝑘k is generated such that the labels of data samples are skewed to classes 2​k−12𝑘12k-1 and 2​k2𝑘2k, with a few samples coming from other classes. This distribution is close to the pathologically non-iid case with two dominant classes. More details about heterogeneous data generation are provided in Appendix.

We consider three types of quantization errors: ϵwsubscriptitalic-ϵw\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}} denotes the model parameter quantization error, ϵgsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔\epsilon_{g} denotes the gradient quantization error, and ϵrsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟\epsilon_{r} denotes the quantization error induced by the server when re-quantizing the aggregated model. Below we use subscripts k𝑘k and t𝑡t to indicate the client and the epoch, respectively. Quantization can be viewed as adding noise to the full precision values, i.e., gk,t(Q)=gk,t+ϵgk,tsubscriptsuperscriptg𝑄𝑘𝑡subscriptg𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡{\textbf{g}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}={\textbf{g}}_{k,t}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t}. In quantized training at client k𝑘k, the update can be expressed as

wk,t+1(Q)=wk,t(Q)−αt​(gk,t+ϵgk,t)+ϵwk,tsuperscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡1𝑄superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄subscript𝛼𝑡subscriptg𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{\textbf{w}}_{k,t+1}^{(Q)}={\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)}-\alpha_{t}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t})+\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}

where wk,t(Q)superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄{\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)} denotes the low-bitwidth model parameters at time t𝑡t, ϵgk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{g_{k},t} is the noise added to the gradient in the quantization step, and ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t} denotes the noise added to the model parameters after gradient update as the parameters retain low-bitwidth representation. After E𝐸E local training epochs, the server collects the models and aggregates them according to

wt+E,G=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​wt+E,k(Q)=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​wk,tQsubscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷superscriptsubscriptw𝑡𝐸𝑘𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄\displaystyle{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,k}^{(Q)}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}{\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{{Q}}
−∑s=0E−1[αt+s​(gk,t+s+ϵgk,t+s)−ϵwk,t+s].superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝐸1delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑡𝑠subscriptg𝑘𝑡𝑠subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡𝑠subscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑠\displaystyle\quad-\sum_{s=0}^{E-1}[\alpha_{t+s}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t+s}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t+s})-\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t+s}].

Since the aggregated model is not necessarily in low bitwidth, an additional re-quantization step is required to form its quantized version wt+E,G(Q)=wt+E,G+ϵr,t+Esuperscriptsubscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺𝑄subscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡𝐸{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G}^{(Q)}={\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G}+\epsilon_{r,t+E}, which is then sent to the clients.

Quantization centers used for layer-wise scalar quantization of the model parameters and gradients are found via companding quantization. Specifically, full-precision input x is transformed by a nonlinear function c𝑐c, e.g., tanh\tanh function, and then uniformly quantized. The output Q​(x)𝑄xQ({\textbf{x}}) is generated by taking the value of the inverse function, c−1superscript𝑐1c^{-1}, of the quantized value [32]. Uniform quantization is a special case of companding quantization obtained by setting c​(x)=x𝑐xxc({\textbf{x}})={\textbf{x}}. In Fed-QSSL, local quantizers can also be viewed as special cases of the companding quantizers.

To proceed with the analysis, we make the following assumption on the quantizers.

Assumption 1.

All quantization operators in the low-bit training are unbiased.

This assumption is commonly encountered in prior work (see, e.g., [30]); an example is the stochastic quantizer, i.e., given a sequence of quantization centers Q1≤⋯≤Q2Rsubscript𝑄1⋯subscript𝑄superscript2𝑅Q_{1}\leq\cdots\leq Q_{2^{R}}, for x∈[Qj,Qj+1]𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗subscript𝑄𝑗1x\in[Q_{j},Q_{j+1}] we have Q​(x)=Qj𝑄𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗Q(x)=Q_{j} with probability Qj+1−xQj+1−Qjsubscript𝑄𝑗1𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗1subscript𝑄𝑗\frac{Q_{j+1}-x}{Q_{j+1}-Q_{j}} and Q​(j)=Qj+1𝑄𝑗subscript𝑄𝑗1Q(j)=Q_{j+1} with probability x−QjQj+1−Qj𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗subscript𝑄𝑗1subscript𝑄𝑗\frac{x-Q_{j}}{Q_{j+1}-Q_{j}}. This assumption implies that quantization errors ϵwsubscriptitalic-ϵw\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}}, ϵgsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔\epsilon_{g}, and ϵrsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟\epsilon_{r} are zero-mean.

We further make the following assumption on gradient estimates, frequently encountered in literature.

Assumption 2.

Expected gradient estimate is unbiased and bounded, 𝔼t​‖gk,t‖2≤G2subscript𝔼𝑡superscriptnormsubscriptg𝑘𝑡2superscript𝐺2\mathbb{E}_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|^{2}\leq G^{2}.

The following lemma provides a bound on the quantization errors (for proof please see Appendix).

Lemma 1.

Suppose Assumptions 1-2 hold, and that client k𝑘k computes update of the quantized model parameters wk,t+1(Q)superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡1𝑄{\textbf{w}}_{k,t+1}^{(Q)} at bitwidth sk=Rsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑅s_{k}=R. Then the gradient quantization error ϵgk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{g_{k},t} satisfies 𝔼t​[‖ϵgk,t‖2]=𝒪​(G2/22​R)subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡2𝒪superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{g_{k},t}\|^{2}]={\mathcal{O}}(G^{2}/2^{2R}), and the local re-quantization error ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t} satisfies 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]=𝒪​(αt​G2/22​R)subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}]={\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}/2^{2R}).

This lemma indicates that by viewing the gradient update αt​(gk,t+ϵgk,t)subscript𝛼𝑡subscriptg𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\alpha_{t}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t}) as a perturbation of wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}, the variance of the weight quantization error ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t} in the local update is of the order 𝒪​(αt​G2)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}). It further implies that the variance of the re-quantization error ϵr,tsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡\epsilon_{r,t} in the global update is of the order 𝒪​(αt​G2​E)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2𝐸{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}E) when αt−E+1=⋯=αtsubscript𝛼𝑡𝐸1⋯subscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t-E+1}=\cdots=\alpha_{t}.

The next corollary readily follows from Lemma 1.

Corollary 1.

Instate the assumptions of Lemma 1, and let all clients use the same learning rate αt−E+1=⋯=αtsubscript𝛼𝑡𝐸1⋯subscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t-E+1}=\cdots=\alpha_{t}. Then there exists Gq=𝒪​(G2/22​R)subscript𝐺𝑞𝒪superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅G_{q}={\mathcal{O}}(G^{2}/2^{2R}) such that 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]≤αt​Gq2subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}]\leq\alpha_{t}G_{q}^{2} and 𝔼t​[‖ϵr,t‖2]≤αt​Gq2subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡2subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{r,t}\|^{2}]\leq\alpha_{t}G_{q}^{2}.

Next, we consider the convergence of the quantized SSL training. Note that objective ℒ=‖X¯−wT​w‖2ℒsuperscriptnorm¯𝑋superscriptw𝑇w2\mathcal{L}=\|\bar{X}-{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2} is generally a non-convex and non-smooth function. In our analysis, we consider a class of functions that satisfies the ρ𝜌\rho-weak convexity.

Definition 1.

A function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\to{\mathbb{R}} is ρ𝜌\rho-weakly convex if f​(x)+ρ2​‖x‖2𝑓𝑥𝜌2superscriptnorm𝑥2f(x)+\frac{\rho}{2}\|x\|^{2} is convex.

Generally, any function of the form f​(x)=g​(h​(x))𝑓𝑥𝑔ℎ𝑥f(x)=g(h(x)), where g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) is convex and Lipschitz and h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) is a smooth map with Lipschitz Jacobian, is weakly-convex. Clearly, the federated SSL objective satisfies ρ𝜌\rho-weak convexity with ρ≥4​‖X¯‖𝜌4norm¯𝑋\rho\geq 4\|\bar{X}\|. To analyze weakly-convex objective function ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, we introduce the Moreau envelope

ϕλ​(x):=miny⁡{ℒ​(y)+12​λ​‖y−x‖2}assignsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥subscript𝑦ℒ𝑦12𝜆superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle\phi_{\lambda}(x):=\min_{y}\{\mathcal{L}(y)+\frac{1}{2\lambda}\|y-x\|^{2}\}

and define the corresponding proximal map as

proxϕλ​(x):=argminy​{ℒ​(y)+12​λ​‖y−x‖2}.assignsubscriptproxsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥subscriptargmin𝑦ℒ𝑦12𝜆superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle\mathrm{prox}_{\phi_{\lambda}(x)}:=\mathrm{argmin}_{y}\{\mathcal{L}(y)+\frac{1}{2\lambda}\|y-x\|^{2}\}.

We use ‖∇ϕλ​(x)‖norm∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥\|\nabla\phi_{\lambda}(x)\| as the convergence indicator. Intuitively, small norm of the gradient of ϕλ​(x)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥\phi_{\lambda}(x) implies that x𝑥x is close to a point x^^𝑥\hat{x} that is stationary for ϕitalic-ϕ\phi. For Fed-QSSL, the following result holds.

Theorem 1.

Suppose all assumptions of Lemma 1 and Corollary 1 hold. For all ρ¯>ρ¯𝜌𝜌\bar{\rho}>\rho, after T𝑇T communication rounds of Fed-QSSL

ϕ1ρ¯​(w0,G(Q))−min⁡ϕ+ρ¯​(G2​∑t=0Tαt​E2+3​Gq2​∑t=0Tαt​E)ρ¯​∑t=0Tαt​E,subscriptitalic-ϕ1¯𝜌subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄0𝐺italic-ϕ¯𝜌superscript𝐺2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝛼2𝑡𝐸3superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscript𝛼𝑡𝐸¯𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇subscript𝛼𝑡𝐸\displaystyle\frac{\phi_{\frac{1}{\bar{\rho}}}({\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{0,G})-\min\phi+\bar{\rho}(G^{2}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\alpha^{2}_{tE}+3G_{q}^{2}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\alpha_{tE})}{\bar{\rho}\sum_{t=0}^{T}\alpha_{tE}},

where E𝐸E denotes the number of local training epochs per communication round (for a total of t​E𝑡𝐸tE training epochs after t𝑡t communication rounds) and w0,G(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄0𝐺{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{0,G} is the quantized parameter initialization.

Theorem 1 implies convergence of the algorithm to a nearly stationary state of the objective function. When αtsubscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t} decreases as 𝒪​(1/t)𝒪1𝑡{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{t}), the upper bound vanishes as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty. The optimal solution w∗superscriptw{\textbf{w}}^{*} of the global objective satisfies ‖∇ϕ1ρ¯​(w∗)‖2=0superscriptnorm∇subscriptitalic-ϕ1¯𝜌superscriptw20\|\nabla\phi_{\frac{1}{\bar{\rho}}}({\textbf{w}}^{*})\|^{2}=0; the vanishing upper bound implies proximity to a neighborhood of the optimal solution.222While using gradient descent estimates with bounded variance typically leads to converge to local minima [28], a property of the SSL objective is that all local minima are global minima [17]. As the quantization rate R𝑅R approaches full precision rate, Gqsubscript𝐺𝑞G_{q} vanishes and the upper bound collapses to the value obtained by vanilla stochastic gradient descent analysis.

It is further of interest to analyze robustness of the learned representations. To this end, we first formally define the representation vector.

Definition 2.

[34] Let 𝒮⊂ℝd𝒮superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{S}\subset{\mathbb{R}}^{d} be the subspace spanned by the rows of the learned feature matrix w∈ℝm×dwsuperscriptℝ𝑚𝑑{\textbf{w}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{m\times d} for the embedding function fw​(x)=w​xsubscript𝑓w𝑥w𝑥f_{{\textbf{w}}}(x)={\textbf{w}}x. The representability of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} is defined as the vector r=[r1,⋯,rd]T𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑟1⋯subscript𝑟𝑑𝑇r=[r_{1},\cdots,r_{d}]^{T} such that ri=‖Π𝒮​(ei)‖2subscript𝑟𝑖superscriptnormsubscriptΠ𝒮subscript𝑒𝑖2r_{i}=\|\Pi_{\mathcal{S}}(e_{i})\|^{2} for i∈[d]𝑖delimited-[]𝑑i\in[d], where Π𝒮​(ei)subscriptΠ𝒮subscript𝑒𝑖\Pi_{\mathcal{S}}(e_{i}) denotes the projection of standard basis eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} onto 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and thus ri=∑j=1s⟨ei,vj⟩2subscript𝑟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗2r_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{s}\langle e_{i},v_{j}\rangle^{2}, s=dim(𝒮)𝑠dimension𝒮s=\dim(\mathcal{S}) and {vj}subscript𝑣𝑗\{v_{j}\} is the set of orthonormal bases of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}.

Vector r𝑟r introduced in this definition quantifies representability by comparing unit bases of different feature spaces. A good feature space should be such that the entries of r𝑟r are large, indicating its standard unit bases can well represent e1,…,edsubscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑑e_{1},\dots,e_{d}, the unit bases in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}.

Theorem 2.

Suppose assumptions of Theorem 1 hold and n=Θ​(d1/20)𝑛Θsuperscript𝑑120n=\Theta(d^{1/20}). In a 2​n2𝑛2n-way classification task, when in local training the update is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon away from the optimal solution wk∗superscriptsubscriptw𝑘{\textbf{w}}_{k}^{*}, the representation vector learned by client k𝑘k with high probability satisfies d2/5−𝒪​(d−2/5)+2​ejT​(wk∗)T​ϵ​ej+(ejT​ϵ)2d2/5+𝒪​(d−2/5)+‖2​(wk∗)T​ϵ+ϵT​ϵ‖≤rik≤1superscript𝑑25𝒪superscript𝑑252superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑇italic-ϵsubscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇italic-ϵ2superscript𝑑25𝒪superscript𝑑25norm2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑇italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘1\frac{d^{2/5}-{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-2/5})+2e_{j}^{T}({\textbf{w}}_{k}^{*})^{T}\epsilon e_{j}+(e_{j}^{T}\epsilon)^{2}}{d^{2/5}+{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-2/5})+\|2({\textbf{w}}_{k}^{*})^{T}\epsilon+\epsilon^{T}\epsilon\|}\leq r_{i}^{k}\leq 1 for i∈[n]\{k}𝑖\delimited-[]𝑛𝑘i\in[n]\backslash\{k\}. As for the global objective, when the update is ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} away from the optimal solution w∗superscriptw{\textbf{w}}^{*}, the learned representation vector r¯¯𝑟\bar{r} with high probability satisfies d2/5−Θ​(d7/20)+𝒪​(d−1/20)−𝒪​(d2/5)+2​ejT​(w∗)T​ϵ1​ej+(ejT​ϵ1)2d2/5−Θ​(d7/20)+𝒪​(d−1/20)+‖2​(w∗)T​ϵ1+ϵ1T​ϵ1‖≤r¯i≤1superscript𝑑25Θsuperscript𝑑720𝒪superscript𝑑120𝒪superscript𝑑252superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇superscriptsuperscriptw𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ12superscript𝑑25Θsuperscript𝑑720𝒪superscript𝑑120norm2superscriptsuperscriptw𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ1superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ1𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript¯𝑟𝑖1\frac{d^{2/5}-\Theta(d^{7/20})+{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-1/20})-{\mathcal{O}}(d^{2/5})+2e_{j}^{T}({\textbf{w}}^{*})^{T}\epsilon_{1}e_{j}+(e_{j}^{T}\epsilon_{1})^{2}}{d^{2/5}-\Theta(d^{7/20})+{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-1/20})+\|2({\textbf{w}}^{*})^{T}\epsilon_{1}+\epsilon_{1}^{T}\epsilon_{1}\|}\leq\bar{r}_{i}\leq 1 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n].

Theorem 2 implies that as ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} vanishes, the entries in representation vectors have strictly positive lower bound and thus do not vanish. This theorem states that the representation space learned from the SSL objectives is such that for the 2​n2𝑛2n basis directions that generate the data, any two clients have similar representability. The theorem further implies that the learned representation vectors are not biased towards local data distributions and are capable of performing well on uniformly distributed data, indicating robustness of the scheme. For the proof of Theorem 2, please see Appendix.

5 Experimental Results

We simulate an FL system with 101010 clients, where the participating clients have different bitwidth configuration and local data distributions. We deploy two bitwidth configurations: (1) the configuration with gradually increasing bitwidth: 20%​4percent20420\%4-bit, 30%​6percent30630\%6–bit, 30%​8percent30830\%8-bit and 20%​12percent201220\%12-bit models; and (2) the configuration with a skewed bitwidth: 50%​6percent50650\%6-bit and 50%​12percent501250\%12-bit models. The experiments involve CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets, both for image classification tasks [20]. The datasets are distributed to clients in a non-iid fashion according to Dirichlet(0.1)0.1(0.1) distribution [1]. Simulations were executed on AMD Vega 202020 GPUs. The learning rates were set as in the following prior work: for the supervised learning schemes using low-bit operations we deploy learning rates as in [40], while for self-supervised learning schemes we follow [34]. In all simulations, the deployed neural networks were based on ResNet-18 architecture [12]. The results are reported after 100100100 communication rounds, with clients running E=20𝐸20E=20 local epochs between any two rounds in CIFAR-10 simulations and E=5𝐸5E=5 in CIFAR-100 simulations. In the implementation of Fed-QSSL, we rely on the SimCLR method [3] for the self-supervision part of the algorithm.333The codes are available at https://github.com/YiyueC/Fed-QSSL.

Baselines. We compare Fed-QSSL with two groups of algorithms: federated supervised learning (SL) and self-supervised algorithms. The SL algorithms include FedAvg [27], classic FL technique performing simple averaging of local models at each communication round; FedProx [22], an FL scheme addressing client data heterogeneity by adding an ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm regularizer to local objectives to prevent divergence of local updates from the global model; and FedPAQ [30], a communication-efficient FL algorithm where clients transmit quantized updates to reduce uplink communication cost. As for the SSL algorithms, we consider Fed-SimCLR [3, 34] which uses contrastive learning objective to learn a global feature extraction model; and Fed-SimSiam [4] which considers only positive pairs of data points and learn meaningful features by leveraging a feature predictor function and stop-gradient operation. While the baseline algorithms are not originally meant to support local low-bit training, we apply low-bitwidth operations to satisfy resource constraints. In each table of results, the last two rows (labeled as “Full”) correspond to full precision (323232-bit) models, i.e., models with no bitwidth constraints.

Metrics. Fed-QSSL is compared to the baselines in terms of global accuracy (Global Acc), reflective of robustness, and local accuracy (Local Acc), reflecting personalization. SSL methods train a universal linear classifier on top of the frozen global feature extraction model and evaluate the classification accuracy on a uniformly distributed test dataset. Training of a linear classifier to be used for testing global model accuracy is conducted at full precision on a centralized training dataset as in [34]; this is done only to validate robustness of SSL methods, in real applications no such universal linear classifier is required. SSL methods use the aggregated model and test on uniform testing dataset. To evaluate local accuracy (i.e., the accuracy on local, generally non-IID datasets), SSL methods train a local linear classifier on top of the frozen low-bitwidth feature extractor while meeting client’s bitwidth constraints and run it on a local non-iid testing dataset, while SL methods use a local low-bitwidth classification model and compute the accuracy on local testing data.

Results. The results on CIFAR-10 under the first bitwidth configuration are reported in Table 1. Overall, the global accuracy of SSL schemes is higher than SL methods, implying that SSL algorithms tend to learn more accurate representations in data heterogeneous FL scenario. As for the personalization, SSL algorithms achieve higher accuracy on local data, suggesting they learn meaningful representations that are then used in the downstream classification task. It is worth noting that SSL algorithms with higher global accuracy also achieve higher local accuracy; this is because the learned robust feature extractor extracts expressive representations from heterogeneous data which help in downstream classification tasks. Among SL algorithms, however, there exists a trade-off between robustness and personalization, where the performance of models with high global accuracy may suffer locally. Specifically, Fed-QSSL performs better in both bitwidth-heterogeneous and no-constrained (full precision) scenarios due to the use of server-side operations on the global buffer; operations on server facilitate learning robust representations that further improve local performance. Table 2 reports results on CIFAR-10 under the second bitwidth configuration. There, SSL algorithms again demonstrate more robust and personalized performance in face of bitwidth and data heterogeneity. As the permitted bitwidth grows, the algorithms reach higher accuracy. Nevertheless, under the bitwidth constraints Fed-QSSL still achieves the highest accuracy. Finally, Table 3 reports results on the more challenging CIFAR-100 dataset. As can be seen there, Fed-QSSL perform better than other SSL benchmarks under both low-bitwidth as well as full precision scenarios.

Computation and Memory Saving. We next compare the computational cost and memory requirements of Fed-QSSL to those of the full precision scheme. In particular, for the two bitwidth configurations and the full precision scenario considered above, we report the number of bitwise operations and memory footprint in the local training (see Figure 2 and Figure 2). In Figure 2, we show the number of bitwise operations for the considered bitwidth configurations; as can be seen there, in both forward and backward pass the computational cost of Fed-QSSL is much smaller than that of the full precision scheme. In low-bit configurations, the backward propagation is consuming more computation because the gradient are represented using 2 bits more than the weights. Figure 2 shows that Fed-QSSL achieves significant memory savings while still providing competitive accuracy.

Ablation Study. Lastly, Figures 5-5 present results of ablation studies. When increasing Dirichlet distribution parameter β𝛽\beta, local data distributions become more uniform and the global accuracy increases. The local accuracy, however, decreases since the clients start facing more classes and thus need to execute more challenging classification tasks (Fig. 3). When smaller size global buffer is used and the ratio of the size of Dgsubscript𝐷𝑔D_{g} and the size of local data decreases, the global accuracy deteriorates while the local accuracy remains mostly unchanged (Fig. 4). Finally, as more training epochs are used in local training, Fed-QSSL achieves higher accuracy (Fig. 5).

6 Conclusion and Future Work

We introduced the federated quantized self-supervised learning (Fed-QSSL) algorithm, an effective framework for FL in bitwidth and data heterogeneity settings. We analytically studied the impact of low-bit training on the convergence and robustness of FL, and experimentally demonstrated that Fed-QSSL achieves more robust and personalized performance than benchmarking algorithms. Future work may include an extension to large-scale settings where it is meaningful to cluster clients with similar data distributions, and train per-cluster models. For such systems, it is of interest to develop schemes that aim to optimally manage utilization of the available resources.

A. Appendix

This section is organized as follows. Section A.1 provides notation and sets up the stage for theoretical analysis. Section A.2-4 present proofs of Lemma 1, Theorem 1 and Theorem 2, respectively. Section A.5 contains details of the local training under low bitwidth constraints.

A.1. Preliminaries

Notation

Let n𝑛n denote the number of clients in a FL system. Client k𝑘k owns dataset Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} containing |Dk|subscript𝐷𝑘|D_{k}| samples drawn independently from distribution 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. Data sample x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in{\mathbb{R}}^{d} is a d𝑑d-dimensional vector. Parameters of the learned SSL model are denoted by w∈ℝm×dwsuperscriptℝ𝑚𝑑{\textbf{w}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{m\times d}. We use [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n] to denote the set {1,2,⋯,n}12⋯𝑛\{1,2,\cdots,n\}. Let ℒℒ\mathcal{L} denote the global objective function, while ℒksubscriptℒ𝑘\mathcal{L}_{k} denotes local objective at client k𝑘k. The inner product of two vectors, x and z, is denoted by ⟨x,z⟩xz\langle{\textbf{x}},{\textbf{z}}\rangle. Finally, let ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| be the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of a vector or Frobenius norm of a matrix, and let ∥⋅∥2\|\cdot\|_{2} denote the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm of a matrix.

Background and settings

We consider a federated learning system with n𝑛n clients participating in model learning via self-supervised learning (SSL). The local objective function used by client k𝑘k is

ℒS​S​L,k​(w)=−𝔼​[(w​(xk,i)+ξk,i)T​(w​(xk,i)+ξk,i′)]+12​‖wT​w‖2,subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿𝑘w𝔼delimited-[]superscriptwsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝜉𝑘𝑖𝑇wsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜉′𝑘𝑖12superscriptnormsuperscriptw𝑇w2\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{SSL,k}({\textbf{w}})=-\mathbb{E}[({\textbf{w}}(x_{k,i})+\xi_{k,i})^{T}({\textbf{w}}(x_{k,i})+\xi^{\prime}_{k,i})]+\frac{1}{2}\|{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2},

where ξk,isubscript𝜉𝑘𝑖\xi_{k,i} and ξk,i′subscriptsuperscript𝜉′𝑘𝑖\xi^{\prime}_{k,i} denote random noise added to the samples. Then the global objective function is defined as ℒS​S​L=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​ℒS​S​L,k​(w)subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿𝑘w\mathcal{L}_{SSL}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}\mathcal{L}_{SSL,k}({\textbf{w}}). The goal of the FL system is to find w that minimizes the global objective. The optimization problem can be written equivalently as min⁡ℒ​(w)=‖X¯−wT​w‖2ℒwsuperscriptnorm¯𝑋superscriptw𝑇w2\min\mathcal{L}({\textbf{w}})=\|\bar{X}-{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2}, where X¯=∑k|Dk||D|​Xk¯𝑋subscript𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscript𝑋𝑘\bar{X}=\sum_{k}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}X_{k} and Xk=𝔼x∼Dk​(x​xT)=1|Dk|​∑i=1|Dk|xk,i​xk,iTsubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥subscript𝐷𝑘𝑥superscript𝑥𝑇1subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝑇X_{k}=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim D_{k}}(xx^{T})=\frac{1}{|D_{k}|}\sum_{i=1}^{|D_{k}|}x_{k,i}x_{k,i}^{T} denotes the empirical data covariance matrix at client k𝑘k. Minimization of the local objective can equivalently be stated as min⁡ℒk​(w)=‖Xk−wT​w‖2subscriptℒ𝑘wsuperscriptnormsubscript𝑋𝑘superscriptw𝑇w2\min\mathcal{L}_{k}({\textbf{w}})=\|X_{k}-{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2}.

Recall that the focus of our analysis is on the impact of low-bit operations deployed in local training on the convergence and robustness of Fed-QSSL. For analytical tractability, we simplify operations at the server by replacing sophisticated de-quantizer by a layer-wise codebook mapping low-bitwidth weights to floating-point values according to wk,t′⁣(Q)=wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw′𝑄𝑘𝑡subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{\prime(Q)}_{k,t}={\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}. The subsequent aggregation follows FedAvg and computes wt,G=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​wk,t′⁣(Q)subscriptw𝑡𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscriptsuperscriptw′𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}_{t,G}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}{\textbf{w}}^{\prime(Q)}_{k,t}, while re-quantization uses the tanh\tanh-based quantizer. For simplicity, we assume that the clients quantize weights/activations using the same bitwidth, i.e., s1=s2=⋯=sn=Rsubscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2⋯subscript𝑠𝑛𝑅s_{1}=s_{2}=\cdots=s_{n}=R; moreover, local gradient quantization is performed using the same number of bits (i.e., sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k}).

Quantization centers used for layer-wise scalar quantization of the model parameters and gradients are found via companding quantization. Specifically, full-precision input x is transformed by a nonlinear function c𝑐c, e.g., tanh\tanh function, and then uniformly quantized. The output Q​(x)𝑄xQ({\textbf{x}}) is generated by taking the value of the inverse function, c−1superscript𝑐1c^{-1}, of the quantized value [32]. Uniform quantization is a special case of companding quantization, obtained by setting c​(x)=x𝑐xxc({\textbf{x}})={\textbf{x}}. In Fed-QSSL, local quantizers can also be viewed as special cases of the companding quantizers. We consider fixed rate quantization, where each codeword (quantization center) used for quantization has the same length. When the quantization rate is R𝑅R, the codebook has K=2R𝐾superscript2𝑅K=2^{R} codewords [32].

We further assume that the quantization noise has zero mean, which can be achieved by adopting stochastic quantization: Given a sequence of quantization centers Q1≤⋯≤Q2Rsubscript𝑄1⋯subscript𝑄superscript2𝑅Q_{1}\leq\cdots\leq Q_{2^{R}}, for x∈[Qj,Qj+1]𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗subscript𝑄𝑗1x\in[Q_{j},Q_{j+1}] we have Q​(x)=Qj𝑄𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗Q(x)=Q_{j} with probability Qj+1−xQj+1−Qjsubscript𝑄𝑗1𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗1subscript𝑄𝑗\frac{Q_{j+1}-x}{Q_{j+1}-Q_{j}} and Q​(j)=Qj+1𝑄𝑗subscript𝑄𝑗1Q(j)=Q_{j+1} with probability x−QjQj+1−Qj𝑥subscript𝑄𝑗subscript𝑄𝑗1subscript𝑄𝑗\frac{x-Q_{j}}{Q_{j+1}-Q_{j}}.

A.2. Proof of Lemma 1

We first review notation featured in the lemma. Let ϵwsubscriptitalic-ϵw\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}} and ϵgsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔\epsilon_{g} denote the error induced by quantizing parameters and gradients, respectively. Let ϵrsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟\epsilon_{r} be the quantization error induced by the server when re-quantizing an aggregated model.

When training at full precision using gradient descent, assuming E𝐸E epochs of local training per communication round, the global model update is formed as

wt+E,G=∑k=1n|Dk||D|​(wt,G−∑s=0E−1αt+s​∂ℒS​S​L,k∂wt+s,k).subscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷subscriptw𝑡𝐺superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝐸1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑠subscriptℒ𝑆𝑆𝐿𝑘subscriptw𝑡𝑠𝑘\displaystyle{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}({\textbf{w}}_{t,G}-\sum_{s=0}^{E-1}\alpha_{t+s}\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{SSL,k}}{\partial{\textbf{w}}_{t+s,k}}).

When performing low-bit quantized training, quantized weights of the model trained by client k𝑘k are found as

wk,t+1(Q)=wk,t(Q)−αt​(gk,t+ϵgk,t)+ϵwk,t,superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡1𝑄superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄subscript𝛼𝑡subscriptg𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{\textbf{w}}_{k,t+1}^{(Q)}={\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)}-\alpha_{t}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t})+\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t},

where wk,t(Q)superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄{\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)} denotes the low-bitwidth model parameters at time t𝑡t, ϵgk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{g_{k},t} is the noise added to the gradient in the quantization step, and ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t} denotes the noise added to the model parameters after gradient update as the parameters retain low bitwidth representation. After E𝐸E local training epochs, the server collects the models and aggregates them according to

wt+E,Gsubscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺\displaystyle{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G} =\displaystyle= ∑k=1n|Dk||D|​wt+E,k(Q)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷superscriptsubscriptw𝑡𝐸𝑘𝑄\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,k}^{(Q)}
=\displaystyle= ∑k=1n|Dk||D|​wk,tQ−∑s=0E−1[αt+s​(gk,t+s+ϵgk,t+s)−ϵwk,t+s].superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛subscript𝐷𝑘𝐷superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑠0𝐸1delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑡𝑠subscriptg𝑘𝑡𝑠subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡𝑠subscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑠\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}{\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{{Q}}-\sum_{s=0}^{E-1}[\alpha_{t+s}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t+s}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t+s})-\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t+s}].

Since the aggregated model is not necessarily in low bit, an additional re-quantization step is required to form its quantized version wt+E,G(Q)=wt+E,G+ϵr,t+Esuperscriptsubscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺𝑄subscriptw𝑡𝐸𝐺subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡𝐸{\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G}^{(Q)}={\textbf{w}}_{t+E,G}+\epsilon_{r,t+E}, which is then sent to clients.

We proceed to Lemma 1, an intermediate result characterizing the variance of quantization errors, 𝔼t​[‖ϵgk,t‖2]subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{g_{k},t}\|^{2}] and 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}]. The lemma shows that given low-bitwidth model parameters and small gradient perturbation, the variance of ϵwsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑤\epsilon_{w} is proportional to the norm of the gradient perturbation. In other words, when a small perturbation is added to low-bitwidth model parameters, the noise induced by quantizing the perturbed parameters has small variance.

For the result in Lemma 1, we need to make the following assumptions.

Assumption 1.

All quantization operators in the low-bit training are unbiased.

Assumption 2.

Expected gradient estimate is unbiased and bounded,

𝔼t​‖gk,t‖2≤G2subscript𝔼𝑡superscriptnormsubscriptg𝑘𝑡2superscript𝐺2\mathbb{E}_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|^{2}\leq G^{2}.

Lemma 1.

Suppose Assumptions 1-2 hold, and that client k𝑘k computes update of the quantized model parameters wk,t+1(Q)superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡1𝑄{\textbf{w}}_{k,t+1}^{(Q)} at bitwidth sk=Rsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑅s_{k}=R. Then the gradient quantization error ϵgk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{g_{k},t} satisfies 𝔼t​[‖ϵgk,t‖2]=𝒪​(G2/22​R)subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡2𝒪superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{g_{k},t}\|^{2}]={\mathcal{O}}(G^{2}/2^{2R}), and the local re-quantization error ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t} satisfies 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]=𝒪​(αt​G2/22​R)subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}]={\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}/2^{2R}).

Proof.

Recall that the quantization in Algorithm 1 is conducted layer-wise. Thus, it suffices to analyze quantization errors for the parameters in the first layer – the results readily extend to the parameters in the remaining layers. Given a local update

wk,t+1(Q)=wk,t(Q)−αt​(gk,t+ϵgk,t)+ϵwk,t,superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡1𝑄superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄subscript𝛼𝑡subscriptg𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\displaystyle{\textbf{w}}_{k,t+1}^{(Q)}={\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)}-\alpha_{t}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t})+\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t},

the gradient update can be viewed as an 𝒪​(αt​‖gk,t‖)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡normsubscriptg𝑘𝑡{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|) perturbation of the corresponding original codebook value. Since 𝔼t​‖gk,t‖2≤G2subscript𝔼𝑡superscriptnormsubscriptg𝑘𝑡2superscript𝐺2\mathbb{E}_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|^{2}\leq G^{2} and we use quantile quantization for gradient compression, the gradient quantization error ϵgk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{g_{k},t} has range within 𝒪​(‖gk,t‖)𝒪normsubscriptg𝑘𝑡{\mathcal{O}}(\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|). Therefore, variance of the gradient quantization error 𝔼t​[‖ϵgk,t‖2]subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{g_{k},t}\|^{2}] is 𝒪​(G2)𝒪superscript𝐺2{\mathcal{O}}(G^{2}).

To analyze weight quantization, let wminsubscriptw{\textbf{w}}_{\min} and wmaxsubscriptw{\textbf{w}}_{\max} be the minimal and maximal value in wk,t(Q)superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄{\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)}, respectively, and let wmin′subscriptsuperscriptw′{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}_{\min} and wmax′subscriptsuperscriptw′{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}_{\max} denote the minimal and maximal value in wk,t(Q)−αt​(gk,t+ϵgk,t)superscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑡𝑄subscript𝛼𝑡subscriptg𝑘𝑡subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}_{k,t}^{(Q)}-\alpha_{t}({\textbf{g}}_{k,t}+\epsilon_{g_{k},t}), respectively. It then holds that |wmin−wmin′|subscriptwsubscriptsuperscriptw′|{\textbf{w}}_{\min}-{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}_{\min}| is 𝒪​(αt​‖gk,t‖)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡normsubscriptg𝑘𝑡{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|) and |wmax−wmax′|subscriptwsubscriptsuperscriptw′|{\textbf{w}}_{\max}-{\textbf{w}}^{\prime}_{\max}| is 𝒪​(αt​‖gk,t‖)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡normsubscriptg𝑘𝑡{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|). By leveraging fixed rate companding quantization with tanh\tanh compander and the fact that the derivative of tanh\tanh decreases from 111 to 00 as the absolute value of the variable increases, it can be shown that the k𝑘k-th codeword in the codebook for wk,t+1(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡1{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t+1} is at most 𝒪​(αt​‖gk,t‖)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡normsubscriptg𝑘𝑡{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}\|{\textbf{g}}_{k,t}\|) away from the k𝑘k-th codeword in the codebook for wk,t(Q)subscriptsuperscriptw𝑄𝑘𝑡{\textbf{w}}^{(Q)}_{k,t}, which implies that by using stochastic quantization operator, the variance of ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}, 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}], is 𝒪​(αt​G2)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}).

In order to derive the relationship between the variance of the quantization error and the quantization rate in Fed-QSSL, we consider two types of quantizations: uniform quantization and companding quantization with optimal compander. Since neural network weights are typically not uniformly distributed but rather follow centered distributions such as Gaussian or Laplacian [14], the uniform quantization MSE, which is 𝒪​(1/22​R)𝒪1superscript22𝑅{\mathcal{O}}(1/2^{2R}) with respect to R𝑅R, can be used as an upper bound on the quantization error. Regarding the lower bound, [32] has shown that the lowest MSE for companding quantization is achieved by the optimal compander with the corresponding MSE 𝒪​(1/22​R)𝒪1superscript22𝑅{\mathcal{O}}(1/2^{2R}) with respect to R𝑅R. Therefore, given the quantization rate R𝑅R, the error of the weight quantizer in Fed-QSSL is 𝒪​(1/22​R)𝒪1superscript22𝑅{\mathcal{O}}(1/2^{2R}). As for the gradient quantizer which relies on the quantile quantization method, one can invoke the quantization MSE of uniform quantization as an upper bound and the MSE of the optimal companding quantization as a lower bound. By combining the two, it follows that the gradient quantization error is 𝒪​(1/22​R)𝒪1superscript22𝑅{\mathcal{O}}(1/2^{2R}). Combining the orders with respect to G𝐺G and R𝑅R, we can complete the proof. ∎

The corollary below follows directly from the lemma.

Corollary 1.

Instate the assumptions of Lemma 1, and let all clients use the same learning rate αt−E+1=⋯=αtsubscript𝛼𝑡𝐸1⋯subscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t-E+1}=\cdots=\alpha_{t} within the same communication round. Then there exists Gq=𝒪​(G2/22​R)subscript𝐺𝑞𝒪superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅G_{q}={\mathcal{O}}(G^{2}/2^{2R}) such that 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]≤αt​Gq2subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}]\leq\alpha_{t}G_{q}^{2} and 𝔼t​[‖ϵr,t‖2]≤αt​Gq2subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡2subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{r,t}\|^{2}]\leq\alpha_{t}G_{q}^{2}.

Proof.

From Lemma 1, when locally performing single-step gradient update, the variance of ϵwk,tsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t} is 𝒪​(αt​G2/22​R)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}/2^{2R}). As for the global update, since all clients run E𝐸E local training epochs, each with constant learning rate, and the update is formed by summing E𝐸E gradient update, the variance of the re-quantization error ϵr,tsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡\epsilon_{r,t} is 𝒪​(αt​G2​E)𝒪subscript𝛼𝑡superscript𝐺2𝐸{\mathcal{O}}(\alpha_{t}G^{2}E). Therefore, there exists Gq=𝒪​(G2/22​R)subscript𝐺𝑞𝒪superscript𝐺2superscript22𝑅G_{q}={\mathcal{O}}(G^{2}/2^{2R}) such that 𝔼t​[‖ϵwk,t‖2]≤αt​Gq2subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵsubscriptw𝑘𝑡2subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{{\textbf{w}}_{k},t}\|^{2}]\leq\alpha_{t}G_{q}^{2} and 𝔼t​[‖ϵr,t‖2]≤αt​Gq2subscript𝔼𝑡delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑟𝑡2subscript𝛼𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑞2\mathbb{E}_{t}[\|\epsilon_{r,t}\|^{2}]\leq\alpha_{t}G_{q}^{2}. ∎

A.3. Proof of Theorem 1

We first review several key definitions and then re-state the theorem. Recall that the global objective ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is non-convex and non-smooth but satisfies weakly-convex assumption. We thus proceed with convergence analysis by relying on techniques encountered in dealing with weakly convex objectives [8].

Recall that a function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:{\mathbb{R}}^{d}\to{\mathbb{R}} is ρ𝜌\rho-weakly convex if f​(x)+ρ2​‖x‖2𝑓𝑥𝜌2superscriptnorm𝑥2f(x)+\frac{\rho}{2}\|x\|^{2} is convex; this definition is readily extended to matrix variable w∈ℝm×dwsuperscriptℝ𝑚𝑑{\textbf{w}}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{m\times d}. In general, any function of the form f​(x)=g​(h​(x))𝑓𝑥𝑔ℎ𝑥f(x)=g(h(x)), where g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) is convex and Lipschitz and h​(⋅)ℎ⋅h(\cdot) is a smooth map with Lipschitz Jacobian, is weakly-convex [8]. Since the global objective function is ℒ=‖X¯−wT​w‖2ℒsuperscriptnorm¯𝑋superscriptw𝑇w2\mathcal{L}=\|\bar{X}-{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2}, it is straightforward to see that the global SSL objective satisfies weak convexity with ρ≥4​‖X¯‖𝜌4norm¯𝑋\rho\geq 4\|\bar{X}\|. For a weakly-convex function ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, the key construction is the Moreau envelope,

ϕλ​(x):=miny⁡{ℒ​(y)+12​λ​‖y−x‖2},assignsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥subscript𝑦ℒ𝑦12𝜆superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle\phi_{\lambda}(x):=\min_{y}\{\mathcal{L}(y)+\frac{1}{2\lambda}\|y-x\|^{2}\},

with the corresponding proximal map defined as

proxϕλ​(x):=argminy​{ℒ​(y)+12​λ​‖y−x‖2}.assignsubscriptproxsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥subscriptargmin𝑦ℒ𝑦12𝜆superscriptnorm𝑦𝑥2\displaystyle\mathrm{prox}_{\phi_{\lambda}(x)}:=\mathrm{argmin}_{y}\{\mathcal{L}(y)+\frac{1}{2\lambda}\|y-x\|^{2}\}.

The convergence can be quantified and tracked via ‖∇ϕλ​(x)‖norm∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥\|\nabla\phi_{\lambda}(x)\|; in particular, small norm of the gradient of ϕλ​(x)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥\phi_{\lambda}(x) implies that x𝑥x is close to a point x^:=proxϕλ​(x)assign^𝑥subscriptproxsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝜆𝑥\hat{x}:=\mathrm{prox}_{\phi_{\lambda}}(x) which is stationary for ϕitalic-ϕ\phi.

While this result demonstrates convergence to a neighborhood of a stationary point, the specific SSL objective, ℒ​(w)=‖X¯−wT​w‖2ℒwsuperscriptnorm¯𝑋superscriptw𝑇w2\mathcal{L}({\textbf{w}})=\|\bar{X}-{\textbf{w}}^{T}{\textbf{w}}\|^{2}, has property that all local minima are global minima [17]. The convergence to local minima via gradient descent using bounded-variance gradient estimates has been studied in [28] under more restrictive conditions including smoothness. It has been shown that for Γ≥λ1​(X¯)Γsubscript𝜆1¯𝑋\Gamma\geq\lambda_{1}(\bar{X}), function ℒ​(w)ℒw\mathcal{L}({\textbf{w}}) is 16​Γ16Γ16\Gamma-smooth within the region {w|‖w‖22≤Γ}conditional-setwsuperscriptsubscriptnormw22Γ\{{\textbf{w}}|\|{\textbf{w}}\|_{2}^{2}\leq\Gamma\}. Thus a suitable choice of ΓΓ\Gamma and step size αtsubscript𝛼𝑡\alpha_{t} guarantee that wtsubscriptw𝑡{\textbf{w}}_{t} remains within the region as long as wt−1subscriptw𝑡1{\textbf{w}}_{t-1} is within the region [17]. Therefore, Fed-QSSL approaches the neighborhood of the local minima of ℒ​(⋅)ℒ⋅\mathcal{L}(\cdot) and, ultimately, that of the global minima.

A.4. Proof of Theorem 2

Heterogeneous data construction. The construction of heterogeneous data follows [34]. Suppose there are n=Θ​(d1/20)𝑛Θsuperscript𝑑120n=\Theta(d^{1/20}) data sets/sources, one for each client, consisting of points that belong to 2​n2𝑛2n classes. For the data set at client k𝑘k, the majority of points belong to classes 2​k−12𝑘12k-1 and 2​k2𝑘2k, while a few remaining points come from other classes. We use e1,…,edsubscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑑e_{1},\dots,e_{d} to denote the standard unit basis of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑{\mathbb{R}}^{d}. Likewise, a data sample from class 2​k2𝑘2k is generated as x(2​k)=−ek−∑i=1,i≠knq(2​k,i)​τ​ei+μ​ξ(2​k−1)superscript𝑥2𝑘subscript𝑒𝑘superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑖1𝑖𝑘𝑛superscript𝑞2𝑘𝑖𝜏subscript𝑒𝑖𝜇superscript𝜉2𝑘1x^{(2k)}=-e_{k}-\sum_{i=1,i\neq k}^{n}q^{(2k,i)}\tau e_{i}+\mu\xi^{(2k-1)}. For simplicity, we assume that all data sets are of the same cardinality, i.e., |Dk||D|=1nsubscript𝐷𝑘𝐷1𝑛\frac{|D_{k}|}{|D|}=\frac{1}{n} for all k∈[n]𝑘delimited-[]𝑛k\in[n].

The following theorem quantifies the robustness property.

Theorem 2.

Suppose assumptions of Theorem 1 hold and n=Θ​(d1/20)𝑛Θsuperscript𝑑120n=\Theta(d^{1/20}). In a 2​n2𝑛2n-way classification task, when in local training the update is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon away from the optimal solution wk∗superscriptsubscriptw𝑘{\textbf{w}}_{k}^{*}, the representation vector learned by client k𝑘k with high probability satisfies d2/5−𝒪​(d−2/5)+2​ejT​(wk∗)T​ϵ​ej+(ejT​ϵ)2d2/5+𝒪​(d−2/5)+‖2​(wk∗)T​ϵ+ϵT​ϵ‖≤rik≤1superscript𝑑25𝒪superscript𝑑252superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑇italic-ϵsubscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇italic-ϵ2superscript𝑑25𝒪superscript𝑑25norm2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptw𝑘𝑇italic-ϵsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘1\frac{d^{2/5}-{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-2/5})+2e_{j}^{T}({\textbf{w}}_{k}^{*})^{T}\epsilon e_{j}+(e_{j}^{T}\epsilon)^{2}}{d^{2/5}+{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-2/5})+\|2({\textbf{w}}_{k}^{*})^{T}\epsilon+\epsilon^{T}\epsilon\|}\leq r_{i}^{k}\leq 1 for i∈[n]\{k}𝑖\delimited-[]𝑛𝑘i\in[n]\backslash\{k\}. As for the global objective, when the update is ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} away from the optimal solution w∗superscriptw{\textbf{w}}^{*}, the learned representation vector r¯¯𝑟\bar{r} with high probability satisfies

d2/5−Θ​(d7/20)+𝒪​(d−1/20)−𝒪​(d2/5)+2​ejT​(w∗)T​ϵ1​ej+(ejT​ϵ1)2d2/5−Θ​(d7/20)+𝒪​(d−1/20)+‖2​(w∗)T​ϵ1+ϵ1T​ϵ1‖≤r¯i≤1superscript𝑑25Θsuperscript𝑑720𝒪superscript𝑑120𝒪superscript𝑑252superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇superscriptsuperscriptw𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑒𝑗superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ12superscript𝑑25Θsuperscript𝑑720𝒪superscript𝑑120norm2superscriptsuperscriptw𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ1superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ1𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript¯𝑟𝑖1\frac{d^{2/5}-\Theta(d^{7/20})+{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-1/20})-{\mathcal{O}}(d^{2/5})+2e_{j}^{T}({\textbf{w}}^{*})^{T}\epsilon_{1}e_{j}+(e_{j}^{T}\epsilon_{1})^{2}}{d^{2/5}-\Theta(d^{7/20})+{\mathcal{O}}(d^{-1/20})+\|2({\textbf{w}}^{*})^{T}\epsilon_{1}+\epsilon_{1}^{T}\epsilon_{1}\|}\leq\bar{r}_{i}\leq 1 for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n].

Technical challenges. While the robustness of w∗superscriptw{\textbf{w}}^{*} was analyzed in [34], it is unclear how to extended it to quantifying robustness when the update obtained by the proposed algorithm approaches the optimal solution. To facilitate such analysis, we initiate it at the step the obtained update is ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1} distance away from the optimal w∗superscriptw{\textbf{w}}^{*}; this maps the problem to that of analyzing perturbed representation vectors and data covariance matrix. We conduct such analysis by borrowing ideas from matrix perturbation theory.

Proof.

∎

A.5. Local Training Implementation Details

Details of local quantized training (steps 5-6 in Fed-QSSL in the main manuscript) are specified in Algorithm 2. In particular, in the forward pass we go from the first layer to the last one, obtain quantized activations along the way; in the backward propagation, we go from the last layer back to the first layer, computing and quantizing gradients in the process.
